Good lord

replies.context: I'm college educated, and they make me sick too.
Ditto.
I taught at the university and college level from 1964 until 2019.  The graduates from the K-12 system were unbelievably worse in 2019 than they were in 1964.  The work ethic changed dramatically.
And that was before stay at home teaching...

I went back to school later in life. On the first day of freshman English I walked into the classroom and written on the white board was:

Its it‚Äôs

To too two

There their they‚Äôre 

She then had to explain what each one meant. A COLLEGE ENGLISH CLASS!!! And no, it wasn‚Äôt a remedial class.

It's not coming from the kid's initial "work ethic."  It's coming from the teachers' "work ethic" - or rather, their severe lack of same.  Parents are lectured before kindergarten that they must NOT teach their kids many normal things, but they MUST teach their kids everything a normal adult would expect the school to teach (physical writing skills, typing, etc.)

Schools pointedly refuse to teach math tables, damaging kids' future speed at more complex problems (new phenomena:  kids are faster at extreme "imaginary numbers" matters than they are at multiplying 7 times 9).  Basic addition methods have been replaced by ridiculous processes that take better drawing skills and half a page of paper for each simple one or two-digit problem.  

Writing isn't taught.  Not the physical skill, not proper letter shaping.  Nothing is repeated enough to develop speed or dexterity, so writing is torture (school excuse:  "Nobody's gonna write in the future; it's all computers!")  No structure is taught:  spelling "rules" are boring and somehow "insulting" to certain "groups," and forget ideas about paragraph or essay structure.  Essays are requested starting in FIRST GRADE, because it's "cute" and who needs to learn form or build up knowledge of communication methodology?  Oh, and "typing" is only taught for a few weeks or months in Kindergarten as a matter of nearly useless online games, where kids hunt-and-peck for letters to save puppies crossing rivers, etc.  So they can't type either

As I try to explain below, it's not that the kids are all that lazy, it's that they really cannot do the work, and are "schooled" to display uncaring, even defiant emotional reactions when the subject comes up.

Elementary schools refuse to teach basics, even simple things like reading a clock, or alphabetical order (letters need to be learned in vocal "developmental" order, which makes NO sense, really).  Kids who raise their hands willingly are declared "rude" (seriously) and their parents hear complaints of "showing off."  Kids who don't raise their hands soon learn that being active in class is loudly punished with insults, so they stay quiet; better to part of the pack getting the teacher's general expression of despair and disdain, than to be singled out for personal abuse).

Parents are assured that the "scattershot" approach to every subject is fine, that "it will all come together" in sixth grade, where everything will miraculously "synthesize" and suddenly our kids will "know" all the math, science, English lit, writing, etc.

But when 6th grade comes, the teachers are upset, and keep repeating that they do not have time to teach what should have been learned before, so they simply won't do it.  They pass them along, too often for social reasons, or by "elevating" lousy work.

The students don't know, or can't fix it.  Being "still" and "conforming" is all they get rewarded for.

My experience was similar to yours and many in my department felt the same way. I taught freshman level courses from 1987 to 2014. The 1990's were not bad, but the new century brought students with no reasoning skills and little knowledge.

context: The 3/5 rule was actually an anti slavery compromise.
